conclusion: Consider the layout of the blocks and the likely path of the car.
The car labeled 'A' is entering from the right side of the image.
The car will likely move in a straight line towards the left unless deflected by a block.
The first block in the car's path is the red block.
The car will collide with the red block first.
After hitting the red block, the car may be deflected slightly.
Depending on the angle of deflection, the car could move towards the green blocks.
The car might then collide with one of the green blocks, possibly the one closest to the red block.
After the second collision, the car could continue moving, potentially hitting another block.
Due to the energy loss from collisions, the car may stop after hitting the second block.
The car is likely to stop after hitting the second block, either the red block and then a green block, or it may stop after hitting the red block if the impact is strong enough to halt it.
The car labeled 'A' will collide with the red block first and then likely hit one of the green blocks. It will eventually stop after these collisions.
